subject: Better late than never
header: This week we have quite a few posts including some that we have missed last week.
Just one note to article authors:
If you would like to remind us about your article the best way is to send us a message to editors@perlweekly.com or to Tweet to us including a link to your post.
Making snide comments about the newsletter just because we have not included your article is not the way to make us happy. Even if you put a fat-smiley on your comment. (Luckily this rarely happens.)

entries.title: How online abuse of women has spiraled out of control
entries.text: A TED talk by Ashley Judd. While her talk focuses on women, one of the commenters points out that statistics about online harassment indicate that men experience even more online harassment. Unfortunately the Perl community is not void of it either. I know I experienced it. I know a friend in Berlin experienced it.

entries.title: v5.26 removes dot from @INC
entries.author: brian_d_foy
entries.text: Up till 5.26 perl used to find modules in the current working directory of the user, that could have been anything. Starting from 5.26 that won't be the case.

entries.title: Perl for High Perfomance; Senior Developer in West London
entries.text: Do you know how to solve problems in terms of queues and caches? Does the idea of truly scaling your architecture on AWS excite you? Not fazed by designing your workloads to be distributed?

entries.title: Fully remote, committed Senior Developer based in the US or Canada
entries.text: All-star Perl team in the US looking for fulltime remote Perl developer based in the US or Canada to work on their SaaS platform.

entries.title: Work with giant, caged robots, and Perl; Senior Developer, West London
entries.text: Let’s start off talking about the robots. They live in cages, they travel at 60mph, and they’re controlled via AMQ messages from a Perl-based Warehouse Management System...
